weaknesses: Devotion: Bound by loyalty to Vishnu
Serpent Curse: Ancient enmity with nagas makes those encounters volatile
Dharmic Restriction: Cannot act against cosmic order
name: Hindu Mythology
abilities: Divine Flight: Unlimited speed and mobility in all realms
Strength: Capable of carrying mountains and gods
Serpent Dominion: Can perceive and combat serpent creatures
Vitality Transfer: Can grant or restore vital energy
Multi-realm Travel: Can traverse physical and spiritual worlds
description: Semi-divine serpent beings inhabiting Patala, guardians of treasures and sacred waters. Major nagas include Shesha, Vasuki, Takshaka, and Kaliya.
habitat: Heavens, sacred mountains, temples dedicated to Vishnu
behavior: Noble and righteous, devoted to Vishnu, protector of dharma (cosmic order)

christian.overview: Hindu Nagas as serpent deities with complex moral characters invite comparison with biblical serpent imagery spanning from Genesis to Revelation.

biblicalParallels.description: The serpent as tempter contrasts with benevolent Nagas; both traditions recognize serpents as wise beings.
The bronze serpent lifted to heal prefigures Christ. This redemptive imagery parallels healing Nagas.
Christ's counsel to be "wise as serpents" recognizes positive serpent qualities like Naga wisdom.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers distinguished between the deceiving serpent and Moses' healing serpent.

sources.author: Justin Martyr
sources.interpretation: The bronze serpent prefigures Christ taking the curse of sin.

comparativeTheology.nagarjuna: The Buddhist philosopher Nagarjuna ("Arjuna of the Nagas") allegedly received teachings from Nagas - paralleling how Scripture often associates serpents with hidden wisdom.
comparativeTheology.waterSymbolism: Nagas as water guardians parallel baptismal symbolism of the deep.

christian.typologicalReading: Naga guardianship of treasures finds Christian parallel in Christ as keeper of wisdom's treasures (Colossians 2:3).
scholarlyReferences: Vogel, J. Ph. Indian Serpent-Lore. London: Arthur Probsthain, 1926.
